items.title: keyword_only and a few other imports missing
items.body:
## Describe the bug

`from pyspark import keyword_only, Row, SQLContext`
- `keyword_only`, `Row`, and `SQLContext` highlight as an error in PyCharm when adding the library to the project. The error is that it `cannot find a reference 'keyword_only' in __init__.py`

- I can do the following to mitigate:
  - `from pyspark.sql.context import SQLContext`
  - `from pyspark.sql.types import Row`
  - But, I can't do anything for `keyword_only`

## To Reproduce

- Minimal code snippet
    ```python
    from pyspark import keyword_only, Row, SQLContext
    ```
## Expected behavior
The IDE shouldn't highlight these imports as errors. 

## Environment
- pyspark-stubs 3.0.0
- Python version: Python 3.6.9
- PySpark version: 3.0.0

## Additional context
If I uninstall `pyspark-stubs` from the project the errors go away. The code still runs fine, PyCharm just shows errors in the IDE.

items.title: Possible wrong type hint in pyspark.sql.functions.format_number
items.body:
## Describe the bug

From the [official document](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/python/pyspark.sql.html), the second argument of `format_number` should be an `int`. However, MyPy reported an error:

```
qq.py: error: Argument 2 to "format_number" has incompatible type "int"; expected "str"
```

## To Reproduce

- Minimal code snippet

    ```python
    from pyspark.sql.functions import col, format_number

    format_number(col("a"), 3)
    ```

- MyPy command

    ```bash
    mypy --config-file mypy.ini ./qq.py
    ```

- MyPy config

    ```ini
    [mypy]
    check_untyped_defs = True
    disallow_any_generics = True
    disallow_incomplete_defs = True
    disallow_subclassing_any = True
    disallow_untyped_calls = True
    disallow_untyped_defs = True
    ignore_missing_imports = True
    no_implicit_optional = True
    no_implicit_reexport = True
    strict_equality = True
    warn_redundant_casts = True
    warn_unused_configs = True
    warn_unused_ignores = True
    ```

## Environment
- pyspark-stubs version: 2.4.0.post8
- MyPy version: 0.740
- Python version: 3.6.9
- PySpark version: 2.4.3

items.title: OneHotEncoder has invalid type for inputCol param
items.body:
## Describe the bug
Given the example:

```python
OneHotEncoder(inputCol=['test'], outputCol='test_new')
```

You'll receive the following error:

> TypeError: Invalid param value given for param "inputCol". Could not convert <class 'list'> to string type

But in the corresponding stub file the param type is defined as `Optional[List[str]] = ...,`. I think It should be `inputCol: Optional[str] = ...,`, even the name of the param `inputCol` indicates a single value.

## Environment
- Python version: 3.6.8 
- PySpark version: 2.4.3

items.title: How to properly annotate pandas_udf functions?
items.body:
## Describe the bug
Hello! This is (probably) not a bug, just a question.
I tried to upgrade from an older version of the stubs to the current one.
This was breaking the annotations for the pandas UDFs, and I don't understand from a first look at the code what I am doing wrong/how I should design the annotation instead.

## To Reproduce

- Minimal code snippet

    ```python
    def _lowercase_text_pd(series: "Series") -> "Series":
        return series.str.lower()

    lowercase_text = F.pandas_udf(_lowercase_text_pd, T.StringType())
    ```

- MyPy command
```bash
error: No overload variant of "pandas_udf" matches argument types "Callable[[Any], Any]", "StringType"
note: Possible overload variants:
note:     def pandas_udf(f: Union[Union[AtomicType, str], ArrayType], returnType: Literal[200]) -> Callable[[<union: 11 items>], UserDefinedFunctionLike]
note:     def pandas_udf(f: Union[StructType, str], returnType: Literal[201]) -> Callable[[Union[Callable[[Any], Any], Callable[[Any, Any], Any]]], GroupedMapPandasUserDefinedFunction]
note:     def pandas_udf(f: Union[Union[AtomicType, str], ArrayType], returnType: Literal[202]) -> Callable[[<union: 11 items>], UserDefinedFunctionLike]
note:     <9 more non-matching overloads not shown>
```

## Environment
- pyspark-stubs version and commit hash (if applicable): 2.4.0.post8
- MyPy version: 2.4.0.post8
- Python version: 3.7.7
- PySpark version: 2.4.6

items.title: Use covariant `Sequence` for `select()`
items.body:
Having an array `a=["col1", "col2"]` the expression `df.select(a)` we get the following mypy error:

```
file.py:10: error: Argument 1 to "select" of "DataFrame" has incompatible type "List[str]"; expected "List[Union[Column, str]]"  [arg-type]
file.py:10: note: "List" is invariant -- see http://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/common_issues.html#variance
file:10: note: Consider using "Sequence" instead, which is covariant
Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```

items.title: boolean for `filter` and `where`
items.body:
Having a dataframe `df` we can do `df.filter(F.col(a) == b)`. Technically this condition is a `Column` (because `DataFrame.__eq__ -> Column`. mypy however here sees a bool and complains about incompatible types.

Applies to 2.4, too.

items.title: Option Values are Optional
items.body:
When setting the options for `DataFrameReader`, `DataFrameWriter` or `DataStreamReader` then `None` is an allowed value.

[DFReader](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/d2ff5c5bfb29a7b22df3cb49b6584c3e2bec397c/python/pyspark/sql/readwriter.py#L124), [DFWriter](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/d2ff5c5bfb29a7b22df3cb49b6584c3e2bec397c/python/pyspark/sql/readwriter.py#L699) and [DSReader](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/d2ff5c5bfb29a7b22df3cb49b6584c3e2bec397c/python/pyspark/sql/streaming.py#L359) are using [`pyspark.sql.utils.to_str()§](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/a4fc6a6e98fcd7ea5ec7a006864ade855c4b5a59/python/pyspark/sql/utils.py#L181)

items.title: Java <-> Python conversion in `pyspark.mllib.common` missing
items.body:
The functions `_py2java` and `_java2py` in `pyspark.mllib.common` are used to transfer objects between the pyspark and the spark side of things.

For some advanced use cases they are required, hence it makes sense to add them to the stubs.

This applies to 2.4.x, too.

items.title: missing default value for `pyspark.sql.functions.to_date`
items.body:
The [stub for `pyspark.sql.functions.to_date`](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/3c4684a224c1be4eea4577e475f8bb4d045edddd/third_party/3/pyspark/sql/functions.pyi#L87) is missing the `= ...` for the second argument [(default `None`)](http://spark.apache.org/docs/3.0.0-preview2/api/python/_modules/pyspark/sql/functions.html#to_date), leading to "too few arguments" errors from mypy.

Same holds true for the `2.4.x` version of the pyspark-stubs.

items.title: [SPARK-30569] Add percentile_approx DSL functions
items.body: https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/27278#issuecomment-600776427

items.title: DataFrame method sampleBy's parameter fractions should be of type dict
items.body:
In the current version, the parameter `fractions` in the sampleBy method of DataFrame is of type float:
```
    def sampleBy(
        self, col: str, fractions: float, seed: Optional[int] = ...
    ) -> DataFrame: ...
```

However, looking at the usage example given in the [pyspark documentation](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/python/pyspark.sql.html#pyspark.sql.DataFrame.sampleBy), it should have been a dictionary, since one needs to define the stratum as well as the sampling ratio.
```
sampled = dataset.sampleBy("key", fractions={0: 0.1, 1: 0.2}, seed=0)
```

items.title: Allow `Column` type for timezone argument in pyspark.sql.functions
items.body:
In the functions here:
https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/3c4684a224c1be4eea4577e475f8bb4d045edddd/third_party/3/pyspark/sql/functions.pyi#L100-L101
we currently have `tz: str` but this can also be specified as a `Column`

Example:
```python
>>> from pyspark.sql import functions
>>> df = spark.sql("SELECT CAST(0 AS TIMESTAMP) AS timestamp, 'Asia/Tokyo' AS tz")
>>> df.select(functions.from_utc_timestamp(df.timestamp, df.tz)).collect()
[Row(from_utc_timestamp(timestamp, tz)=datetime.datetime(1970, 1, 1, 18, 0))]
```

I think this could be expanded to `tz: ColumnOrName`?

items.title: Jedi doesn't work with MLReaders
items.body:
It seems like there is some problem with Jedi compatibility. Some components seem to work pretty well. For example `DataFrame` without stubs:

```
In [1]: import jedi                                                                                                                                                                                                

In [2]: from pyspark.sql import SparkSession                                                                                                                                                                       

In [3]: jedi.Interpreter("SparkSession.builder.getOrCreate().createDataFrame([]).", [globals()]).completions()                                                                                                     
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError   
...
AttributeError: 'ModuleContext' object has no attribute 'py__path__'
```
and with stubs:

```
In [1]: from pyspark.sql import SparkSession                                                                                                                                                                       

In [2]: import jedi                                                                                                                                                                                                

In [3]: jedi.Interpreter("SparkSession.builder.getOrCreate().createDataFrame([]).", [globals()]).completions()                                                                                                     
Out[3]: 
[<Completion: agg>,
 <Completion: alias>,
 <Completion: approxQuantile>,
 <Completion: cache>,
 <Completion: checkpoint>,
 <Completion: coalesce>,
 <Completion: collect>,
 <Completion: colRegex>,
 <Completion: columns>,
 <Completion: corr>,
 <Completion: count>,
 <Completion: cov>,
...
 <Completion: __str__>]
```

So far so good. However, if take for example `LinearRegressionModel.load` things don't work so well. Without stubs provides no suggestions

```
In [1]: import jedi                                                                                                                                                                                                

In [2]: from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegressionModel                                                                                                                                                    

In [3]: jedi.Interpreter("LinearRegressionModel.load('foo').", [globals()]).completions()                                                                                                                          
Out[3]: []
```

but one provided with stubs

```
In [1]: import jedi                                                                                                                                                                                                

In [2]: from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegressionModel                                                                                                                                                    

In [3]: jedi.Interpreter("LinearRegressionModel.load('foo').", [globals()]).completions()                                                                                                                          
Out[3]: 
[<Completion: load>,
 <Completion: read>,
 <Completion: __annotations__>,
 <Completion: __class__>,
 <Completion: __delattr__>,
 <Completion: __dict__>,
 <Completion: __dir__>,
 <Completion: __doc__>,
 <Completion: __eq__>,
 <Completion: __format__>,
 <Completion: __getattribute__>,
 <Completion: __hash__>,
 <Completion: __init__>,
 <Completion: __init_subclass__>,
 <Completion: __module__>,
 <Completion: __ne__>,
 <Completion: __new__>,
 <Completion: __reduce__>,
 <Completion: __reduce_ex__>,
 <Completion: __repr__>,
 <Completion: __setattr__>,
 <Completion: __sizeof__>,
 <Completion: __slots__>,
```

don't make much sense. If model is fitted:

```
In [4]: from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegression                                                                                                                                                         

In [5]: jedi.Interpreter("LinearRegression().fit(...).", [globals()]).completions()                                                                                                                                
Out[5]: 
[<Completion: aggregationDepth>,
 <Completion: append>,
 <Completion: clear>,
 <Completion: coefficients>,
 <Completion: copy>,
 <Completion: count>,
....
 <Completion: __str__>]
```

Model which is explicitly annotated works fine, so it seems like there is something in `MLReader` or one of the sub-classes that causes a failure.

We already have data tests for this (as well as some test cases from [apache/spark examples](https://github.com/apache/spark/tree/master/examples), and mypy seems to be fine with this.

Since `LinearRegression.fit` works fine (and some toy tests confirm that), `Generics` are not sufficient to reproduce the problem. So it seems like type parameter is not processed correctly on the path:

-  [`LinearRegressionModel(..., avaMLReadable[LinearRegressionModel], ...)`](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/c93d132392657334a137d32b69d852a7c8abdafa/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/regression.pyi#L38) 
- [`JavaMLReadable(MLReadable[R])`](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/c93d132392657334a137d32b69d852a7c8abdafa/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/util.pyi#L76) 
- [`MLReadable(Generic[R])`](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/c93d132392657334a137d32b69d852a7c8abdafa/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/util.pyi#L70) 
- [`load(cls, path: str) -> R`](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/c93d132392657334a137d32b69d852a7c8abdafa/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/util.pyi#L74)

Tested with:

- `jedi==0.15.2` and `jedi==0.16.0` ([0c56aa4](https://github.com/davidhalter/jedi/commit/0c56aa4d4be211b2fd691dcd68fc1b06de2c6c52)).
- `pyspark-stubs==3.0.0.dev5`
- `pyspark==3.0.0.dev0` ([afe70b3](https://github.com/apache/spark/commit/afe70b3b5321439318a456c7d19b7074171a286a))

items.title: Missing Param in pyspark.ml.LinearRegression
items.body:
Following `Param` values are missing:

- `solver`
- `loss`
- `epsilon`

as well as corresponding getters and setters.

items.title: Incorrect return type of Params.hasParams
items.body: Is `Param`, should be `bool`.

items.title: Incorrect ALS.coldStrategy Param
items.body: Is `coldStrategy`, should be `coldStartStrategy`.

items.title: DataFrameReader.load parameters incorrectly expected all to be strings
items.body:
Using 2.4.0.post6

```python
spark.read.load(folders, inferSchema=True, header=False)
```

mypy reports `Expected type 'str', got 'bool' instead` for both `inferSchema` and `header`.

Looks like the issue is in `third_party/3/pyspark/sql/readwriter.pyi` Line 23 where in the definition for `load()` we have `**options: str`.  For csv suppport this needs to be `**options: Optional[Union[bool, str, int]]` but to handle the general case  it probably needs to be `**options: Any`.

items.title: Comparisons with date values unsupported
items.body:
Using *2.4.0.post6*

```from datetime import date
sf.lit(date.today()) < date.today()
```

mypy reports  ```Unsupported operand types for < ("Column" and "date")```

I suspect the solution is as simple as changing the definitions of lt, gt, lte, gte etc in master/third_party/3/pyspark/sql/column.pyi from `Union[Column, LiteralType, DecimalLiteral])` to `Union[Column, LiteralType, DecimalLiteral, DateTimeLiteral])` `DateTimeLiteral` is already imported but appears not to be used.

items.title: Unsafe overlap in pandas_udf
items.body:
Unfortunately decorators for Pandas scalar udf overlap unsafely between scalar-to-scalar and scalar-to-struct variants. The culprit is return type:

- scalar-to-scalar uses `Union[AtomicDataTypeOrString, ArrayType]`
- scalar-to-struct uses `Union[StructType, str]`

and `OrString` (in `AtomicDataTypeOrString`) ans `str` cause overlap.

One possible solution is to disallow `str` schema for on of these, preferably scalar-to-scalar:

```
def pandas_udf(f: Union[AtomicType, ArrayType], returnType: PandasScalarUDFType) -> Callable[[PandasScalarToScalarFunction], UserDefinedFunctionLike]: ...
```

items.title: SparkSession.createDataFrame should accept Iterable[Tuple] and StructType
items.body:
> @zero323 According to the [documentation](https://spark.apache.org/docs/2.4.0/api/python/pyspark.sql.html#pyspark.sql.SparkSession.createDataFrame), it is possible to create a DataFrame with the usage of the proper schema and the data which are a list e.g. `List[tuple]`.
I have prepared the example of the code which is not proper against `mypy` but it is proper against `pyspark` and it works properly, at least in my opinion 😅

```python
data = [('Alice', 1)]
schema = StructType([
    StructField("name", StringType(), True),
    StructField("age", IntegerType(), True)
])

# a properly created DataFrame, unfortunately with lost "IntegerType"
spark.createDataFrame(data, ['name', 'age'])

# a properly created DataFrame unfortunately `mypy` is telling about incompatible used type
spark.createDataFrame(data, schema)
```

> The exact error produced by `mypy` is as followed:
```
error: Argument 1 to "createDataFrame" of "SparkSession" has incompatible type "List[Tuple[str, int]]"; expected "Union[RDD[Union[datetime, date, bool, int, float, str, Decimal]], List[Union[datetime, date, bool, int, float, str, Decimal]]]"
```


_Originally posted by @redlickigrzegorz in https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/issues/115#issuecomment-539021784_

items.title: mypy segmentation fault due to udf
items.body:
I encountered this issue when tried to upgrade from `2.4.0.post5` to `2.4.0.post6`. Here are the steps to reproduce the error:

```sh
$ python --version
Python 3.7.3
$ python -m venv venv
$ source ./venv/bin/activate
(venv) $ pip install pyspark==2.4.3 pyspark-stubs==2.4.0.post6 mypy==0.720
(venv) $ echo "from pyspark.sql.functions import udf" > a.py
(venv) $ mypy -v .
LOG:  Could not load plugins snapshot: @plugins_snapshot.json

LOG:  Mypy Version:           0.720
LOG:  Config File:            Default
LOG:  Configured Executable:  /tmp/pysp/venv/bin/python
LOG:  Current Executable:     /tmp/pysp/venv/bin/python
.
.
.
LOG:  Writing pyspark.sql /tmp/pysp/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyspark/sql/__init__.pyi pyspark/sql/__init__.meta.json pyspark/sql/__init__.data.json
LOG:  Cached module pyspark.sql has changed interface
LOG:  Writing pyspark /tmp/pysp/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyspark/__init__.pyi pyspark/__init__.meta.json pyspark/__init__.data.json
LOG:  Cached module pyspark has changed interface
LOG:  Processing SCC singleton (pyspark.sql.functions) as inherently stale with stale deps (builtins pyspark.sql._typing pyspark.sql.column pyspark.sql.dataframe pyspark.sql.types typing)
[1]    21994 segmentation fault (core dumped)  mypy -v .
```

The error will disappear if the following lines are removed:

https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/a85230ee1d8f70d5d0a14ff5b3b84cccd848e942/third_party/3/pyspark/sql/functions.pyi#L244-L245

items.title: Param.parent  is not Param
items.body: `Param.parent` expects `pyspark.ml.util.Identifiable` object, not `Param`.

items.title: Params should be Generic
items.body: While the current solution works pretty well, using generic should enable additional type checks and prove useful in the future. It will also mimic Scala counterpart.

items.title: Running mypy on `import pyspark.sql.functions` results in segmentation fault
items.body:
with `pyspark-stubs==2.4.0.post6`: 
```
$ mypy -c 'import pyspark.sql.functions'
Segmentation fault: 11
```

with `pyspark-stubs==2.4.0.post5`:
```
$ mypy -c 'import pyspark.sql.functions'
Success: no issues found in 1 source file
```

I'm using python 3.7.4, `mypy==0.730` and `pyspark==2.4.3`

items.title: Use literals as evaluation metric names
items.body:
Since available evaluates support fixed set of metrics, we could replace current annotations (` metricName: str = ...`) with `Evaluators` specific `Union` of `Literals`, i.e.

```python
from typing_extensions import Literal
from typing import Union

RegressionEvaluatorMetrics = Union(Literal["rmse"], Literal["mse"], Literal["r2"], Literal["mae"], Literal["var"])
```

items.title: ML transformer __init__ and setParams should be keyword only
items.body: All ML transformers use `keyword_only` decorator on `__init__` and `setParams`. Since we support only Python 3, we could mark all these methods as keyword only.

items.title: Indicate mutually exclusive inputCol(s) / outputCol(s) pairs
items.body:
There is growing number of ML transformers that support either single column to single column transormations (`inputCol` to `outputCol`) or columns to columns transformations (`inputCols` to `outputCols`). Mutually exclusive parameters are use in `__init__` and `setParams`:

- [`StringIndexer`](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/3e2649287d98b9692fdd1025e1bf8fe8d3de768e/python/pyspark/ml/feature.py#L2740-L2762)
- [`QuantileDiscretizer`](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/3e2649287d98b9692fdd1025e1bf8fe8d3de768e/python/pyspark/ml/feature.py#L2075-L2099)
- [`Bucketizer`](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/3e2649287d98b9692fdd1025e1bf8fe8d3de768e/python/pyspark/ml/feature.py#L419-L442)

It makes sense to `overload` these signatures.

items.title: DataFrame.distinct is not supported in 2.4.0.postX
items.body:
It seems this function has existed since 1.3:
https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/1b99d0cca4b4fb6d193091f92c46c916b70cd84e/python/pyspark/sql/dataframe.py#L776-L783

items.title: UDFRegistration and UserDefinedFunction haven't been updated after SPARK-22409
GROUPED_MAP Pandas UDF should support binary function
items.body: See [SPARK-23011](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-23011).

items.title: SCALAR pandas_udf should support complex output
items.body:
Since Spark 3.0 ([SPARK-23836](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-23836)) `SCALAR` UDF supports complex return types.

It seems like we'll have to split `PandasScalarFunction` into something like

- `PandasScalarToScalarFunction` - taking `Callable[[...], pandas.core.series.Series]` 
- `PandasScalarToStructFunction` - taking  `Callable[[...], pandas.core.frame.DataFrame]` 

There is possible trade-off here - right now we have

```python
@overload
def pandas_udf(f: PandasScalarFunction, returnType: Union[AtomicDataTypeOrString, ArrayType], functionType: PandasScalarUDFType) -> UserDefinedFunctionLike: ...
```

after split we'll need at least:

```python
@overload
def pandas_udf(f: PandasScalarToScalarFunction, returnType: Union[AtomicDataType, ArrayType], functionType: PandasScalarUDFType) -> UserDefinedFunctionLike: ...

@overload
def pandas_udf(f: PandasScalarToStructFunction, returnType: StructType, functionType: PandasScalarUDFType) -> UserDefinedFunctionLike: ...
```

That leaves `str` schema. which can lead to some ambiguity.

items.title: UDFRegistration.register should support str return type.
items.body: See discussion in #187

items.title: hint of lit, col in pyspark.sql.functions
items.body: Is it possible to add the hint for lit, col in pyspark.sql.functions

items.title: DataStreamReader.schema should support str argument
items.body:
Right it is 

https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/9a8ffe9ad1d3e6020d9c31b262faa1b3b3fae926/third_party/3/pyspark/sql/streaming.pyi#L49

It should be

```python
    def schema(self, schema: Union[StructType, str]) -> DataStreamReader: ...
```

Related to #175, #176

items.title: Are RDD.filter and DStream.filter annotations to restrictive?
items.body:
Right now we expect `Callable[[T], bool` in both cases 
https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/9a8ffe9ad1d3e6020d9c31b262faa1b3b3fae926/third_party/3/pyspark/rdd.pyi#L75 

and 

https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/9a8ffe9ad1d3e6020d9c31b262faa1b3b3fae926/third_party/3/pyspark/streaming/dstream.pyi#L23

however in practice and truthy of falsy value will do, and there are some valid use cases where the users might want to use that fact:

```python

sc.textFile(...).filter(lambda x: x)
```

items.title: pylint vscode?
items.body:
does this help with pylint warnings on vscode by any chance? I tried it out and the warnings kept appearing, wasn't sure if I was using it wrong.

for now I followed the advice in this SO answer: https://stackoverflow.com/a/52119469/1667241

```
"python.linting.pylintArgs": [
        "--generated-members=pyspark.*",
        "--extension-pkg-whitelist=pyspark",
        "--ignored-modules=pyspark.sql.functions"
    ]
```

was hoping there was a better solution. thanks!

items.title: Consider testing against pytype
items.body:
Right now we test only against Mypy. It might worth considering testing against [pytype](https://github.com/google/pytype) as well.

That however might be to much overhead. Keeping up with mypy alone is time consuming, and another type checker might make things even worse.

items.title: Add static annotations for DataFrame.mapInPandas
items.body: Since usptream API is still under discussion ([SPARK-28264](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-28264)), and improved UDF annotations are still work in progress (#142), let's keep quasi-dynamic (4a1da21) annotation for now, and revisit this later.

items.title: Add support for decorator UDFs
items.body:
Currently we support only direct application of `udf` (and `pandas_udf`). In other words this will type check:

```python
from pyspark.sql.functions import col, udf
from pyspark.sql.column import Column

def f(x: int) -> int:
    return x

f_ = udf(f, "str")
f_(col("foo"))
```

but this, won't

```python
from pyspark.sql.functions import col, udf
from pyspark.sql.column import Column

@udf("str")
def g(x: int) -> int:
    return x

g(col("foo"))

foo.py:4: error: Argument 1 to "udf" has incompatible type "str"; expected "Callable[..., Any]"
foo.py:4: error: Argument 1 to "__call__" of "UserDefinedFunctionLike" has incompatible type "Callable[[int], int]"; expected "Union[Column, str]"
foo.py:8: error: "Column" not callable
```

I guess we can address that providing overloaded variant (not tested):

```python
@overload
def udf(f: Callable[..., Any], returnType: DataTypeOrString = ...) -> Callable[..., Column]: ...
@overload
def udf(f: DataTypeOrString = ...) -> Callable[[Callable[..., Any]], Callable[..., Column]]: ...
```

Related to #142, #143

Blocked by https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/7243

items.title: Simplify test matrix
items.body:
Right now we explicitly test annotations against 3.5, 3.6 and 3.7. However that is a bit wasteful, as we already run mypy against multiple targets with different `--python-version`.

It seems that we could speed up the tests and reduce load on Travis, by keeping only the latest Python version.

items.title: Update variable annotation to new style
items.body:
We have a bunch of old style

    foo = ....  # type: bar

annotations. Since Python 3.6 has been around for a while, and there is no indication that this project will be merged with main Spark repository, we could update these to new style, i.e.

    foo: bar = ...

items.title: HasWeightCol is missing from OneVsRestParams
items.body: Applies to 2.3, 2.4, and master

items.title: Enable new semantic analyzer once it is fixed
items.body: See #152

items.title: Must not defer during final iteration with new mypy analyzer
items.body:
While using new mypy analyzer tests fail with

```
AssertionError: Must not defer during final iteration
```

Possibly related to python/mypy#7129

Interestingly it works in the second run, when MyPy cache exists.

For now we can freeze mypy version to e7ddba113d69055387996df33ceaace52b8c2c97 and revisit this later.

items.title: Repeated ParaMap definitions are incompatible with new mypy analyzer
items.body:
Right now we define `ParamMap` in multiple places. It not only violates DRY, but is also incompatible with new mypy analyzer: 

```
Cannot assign multiple types to name "ParamMap" without an explicit "Type[...]" annotation
```

items.title: pyspark.ml.param.shared.TypeVar(T) conflicts with other TypeVar definitions
items.body:
- [In `shared` we define `T` `Typevar`]( https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/0cd94f527352a3c8bd2f6c2119f1111783895a8d/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/param/shared.pyi#L7)
- Similarly we define `T` in different modules, as placeholders for `Params`  types. For example in [`regression`](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/0cd94f527352a3c8bd2f6c2119f1111783895a8d/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/regression.pyi#L11)

Because [`pyspark.ml.param.shared` are star imported](https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/0cd94f527352a3c8bd2f6c2119f1111783895a8d/third_party/3/pyspark/ml/regression.pyi#L5) this creates a conflict in the latest `mypy` builds ([with new semantic analyzer enabled](https://github.com/python/mypy/commit/dc58be0a2c1aeed3965cf87490bdf3ebdad2afb1)).

```
... error: Cannot redefine 'T' as a type variable
```

See python/mypy#7185

items.title: Review changes in core pyspark in 3.0.0
Provide more precise UDF annotations
items.body:
Currently udfs (especially vectorized ones) have rather crude annotations, which don't really capture actual relationships between arguments.

This can be improved by using literal types and protocols.

Related to #125, #137

items.title: BlockMatrix initializer should take Matrix not MatrixEntry
items.body: https://github.com/zero323/pyspark-stubs/blob/07b1c576d2a8ab825b317d072801063a9a97a96c/third_party/3/pyspark/mllib/linalg/distributed.pyi#L81

items.title: Some functions take only Column type as argument
items.body:
Hi,

I noticed while trying to use the `upper` function that if the argument passed is a String we got the following error: 

```
py4j.protocol.Py4JError: An error occurred while calling z:org.apache.spark.sql.functions.upper. Trace:
py4j.Py4JException: Method upper([class java.lang.String]) does not exist
```
It makes sense as [only upper(e: Column) is implemented in Scala](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/58301018003931454e93d8a309c7149cf84c279e/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/functions.scala#L2622)

Some methods (like floor) do have both Column and String parameter overload, but some (like upper) don't, so the stubs for those methods should indicate `Column` type instead of `ColumnOrName`.

items.title: Add 'back compatibility' imports to spark package
items.body:
As of `v2.4.0`, pyspark has some 'back compatibility' imports in the `spark` package that are missing in the stub:
https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/v2.4.0/python/pyspark/__init__.py#L114 

Can we add them?

items.title: Review Callable usage
items.body: At least in some cases we can replace `Callable` with more precise `Protocols`.

items.title: Refine RDD.toDF annotation
items.body:
Right now we simply allow `RDD[Tuple]`, but it is not very precise. A more precise annotations will require an extended literal definition.

Related to #115

items.title: Improve createDataFrame annotations
items.body:
Right now `createDataFrame` are rather crude. It would be great refine these, to check dependencies between different type of arguments:

- `RDD[Literal]` or `List[Literal]` requires schema string or `DataType`.
- Schema (DDL string or DataType) is exclusive with `samplingRatio`.
- `verifySchema` is meaningful only if schema has been provided.
- Input should be `Literal` or `Tuple` / `List` of `Literals`, `Tuples`, `List[Literal]`, `Dict[Literal, Literal]`.

items.title: HasMaxIter should return Type[self] not  HasMaxIter
Consider using Protocols to replace NumberOrArray
Params should return self type.
items.body: Right now `pyspark.ml.Params` return corresponding mixin type. While technically speaking correct it is not very useful in practice.

items.title: Review changes in pyspark.streaming in Spark 2.4
Review changes in pyspark.sql in Spark 2.4
Review changes in pyspark.mllib in Spark 2.4
Review changes in pyspark.ml in Spark 2.4
Review changes in core pyspark in  PySpark 2.4
Inconsistent type of instance argument pyspark.ml.util.JavaMLWriter.__init__
items.body: Is `Param` should be `JavaMLWriteable`.

items.title: Improve tests
items.body:
To ensure correctness of the annotation we should validate these against actual code.

A good starting point would be to run `mypy` against all PySpark examples.

items.title: Consider making MLReadable / MLReader generic in terms of loaded object
